resources.string: There are five general categories of programming errors: syntax, semantic, logical, compile time, and runtime errors.

Syntax errors are caused by an incorrect sequence of characters that are intended to be written in a particular programming language. Semantic errors refer to valid code the compiler understands, but they do not do what you intended. Logical errors are errors inherited from a flaw in the base algorithm, making the logic on which the program is based on false. Compile time errors are the result of syntax errors and semantic errors indicated by the compiler. Runtime errors refer to more semantic errors and logical errors that cannot be detected by the compiler.
